group.id: Q:MRK 16.19+What do you think it means when it says that Jesus sat down at the right hand side of God?

trans-unit.id: a:!MRK!16~19#Answer:What do you think it means when it says that Jesus sat down at the right hand side of God?-1597953858
trans-unit.source: In Jewish custom the right hand side of important people was the most honored position anyone could ever have. His position there also shows his great authority along with God over the universe.
trans-unit.target: In Jewish custom the right hand side of important people was the most honoured position anyone could ever have. His position there also shows his great authority along with God over the universe.
trans-unit.note: !MRK!16~19#Answer:What do you think it means when it says that Jesus sat down at the right hand side of God?

group.id: Q:MAT 1.22-23+Who do you think God is?

trans-unit.id: n:!MAT!1~22#Note:Who do you think God is?-985838223
trans-unit.source: In many languages the term for God is a proper name and cannot be used to refer to anyone except the one supreme creator of the world. It cannot be pluralized. (Or, if it can be pluralized, the meaning may be something very different from the English "gods".) (See "God" in KBT.)
trans-unit.target: In many languages the term for God is a proper name and cannot be used to refer to anyone except the one supreme creator of the world. It cannot be pluralised. (Or, if it can be pluralised, the meaning may be something very different from the English "gods".) (See "God" in KBT.)
trans-unit.note: !MAT!1~22#Note:Who do you think God is?

group.id: Q:MAT 3.7-10+What do you think was the reason that John was not glad that the Pharisees and Sadducees came to him to be baptized?

trans-unit.id: a:!MAT!3~7#Answer:What do you think was the reason that John was not glad that the Pharisees and Sadducees came to him to be baptized?-2025869504
trans-unit.source: He was not glad because he knew that they did not come wanting/in pursuit of a right relationship with God. They were just acting as though they agreed with John's teaching about repenting and worshiping God so that others would think well of them. (7-10)
trans-unit.target: He was not glad because he knew that they did not come wanting/in pursuit of a right relationship with God. They were just acting as though they agreed with John's teaching about repenting and worshipping God so that others would think well of them. (7-10)
trans-unit.note: !MAT!3~7#Answer:What do you think was the reason that John was not glad that the Pharisees and Sadducees came to him to be baptized?

group.id: Q:MAT 3.11-12+When John said that Jesus would "baptize with the Holy Spirit and fire", what do you think he meant by "fire"? (This is a check for any obviously wrong meaning.)

trans-unit.id: a:!MAT!3~11#Answer:When John said that Jesus would "baptize with the Holy Spirit and fire", what do you think he meant by "fire"? (This is a check for any obviously wrong meaning.)1974023063
trans-unit.source: 2) Fire is used to indicate punishment/judgment from God by association with the pain of burning. Such punishment/judgment would usually apply to non-believers in the New Testament.
trans-unit.target: 2) Fire is used to indicate punishment/judgement from God by association with the pain of burning. Such punishment/judgement would usually apply to non-believers in the New Testament.
trans-unit.note: !MAT!3~11#Answer:When John said that Jesus would "baptize with the Holy Spirit and fire", what do you think he meant by "fire"? (This is a check for any obviously wrong meaning.)

trans-unit.id: n:!MAT!3~11#Note:When John said that Jesus would "baptize with the Holy Spirit and fire", what do you think he meant by "fire"? (This is a check for any obviously wrong meaning.)1916805208
trans-unit.source: From John's concern that, at least some of them, might depend on their status of being descendants of Abraham and miss God's blessing, he could be referring to some of them as being baptized with the Holy Spirit and others being baptized with fire. This would then make fire here mean about the same as in verses 10 and 12, where it means judgment/punishment.
trans-unit.target: From John's concern that, at least some of them, might depend on their status of being descendants of Abraham and miss God's blessing, he could be referring to some of them as being baptized with the Holy Spirit and others being baptized with fire. This would then make fire here mean about the same as in verses 10 and 12, where it means judgement/punishment.

group.id: Q:MAT 6.12+What do you think happens when a person/someone forgives someone else?

trans-unit.id: a:!MAT!6~12#Answer:What do you think happens when a person/someone forgives someone else?2111506392
trans-unit.source: Key Term Check: Forgiveness always involves two people, one of whom has done something wrong to the other and offended him. Forgiveness takes place when the one, who was offended, sets aside his right to justice and decides not to punish the offender, as he deserved. If the one who offended repents and accepts this forgiveness, the result is that the relationship between the two, which was broken by the offense, is restored and the guilt of the offender is removed.
trans-unit.target: Key Term Check: Forgiveness always involves two people, one of whom has done something wrong to the other and offended him. Forgiveness takes place when the one, who was offended, sets aside his right to justice and decides not to punish the offender, as he deserved. If the one who offended repents and accepts this forgiveness, the result is that the relationship between the two, which was broken by the offence, is restored and the guilt of the offender is removed.
trans-unit.note: !MAT!6~12#Answer:What do you think happens when a person/someone forgives someone else?

group.id: Q:MAT 9.4+What does it mean to you to talk about the "heart"?

trans-unit.source: Key Term Check: The most common use of the word "heart" in the Bible is to refer to the spiritual center or innermost part of a human being. In Hebrew and Greek, "heart" is most commonly associated with thoughts and ideas.
trans-unit.target: Key Term Check: The most common use of the word "heart" in the Bible is to refer to the spiritual centre or innermost part of a human being. In Hebrew and Greek, "heart" is most commonly associated with thoughts and ideas.
trans-unit.note: !MAT!9~1#Answer:What does it mean to you to talk about the "heart"?

trans-unit.source: Check for possible mismatch with local practice. At least Jesus and his hearers did not usually patch new cloth onto old cloth.

trans-unit.note: !MAT!9~16#Note:Do people you know sometimes repair an old garment with a piece of new cloth?

group.id: Q:MAT 9.16-17+What do you think is the reason that Jesus spoke here about cloth, and about the wine and about hardened leather containers/bottles? What was he teaching the people?

trans-unit.id: a:!MAT!9~16#Answer:What do you think is the reason that Jesus spoke here about cloth, and about the wine and about hardened leather containers/bottles? What was he teaching the people?-519655695
trans-unit.source: He taught them that his teachings could not be a part of their old teachings/traditions/traditional system. They needed to change what they believed and also to change their way of worshiping God. (16-17)
trans-unit.target: He taught them that his teachings could not be a part of their old teachings/traditions/traditional system. They needed to change what they believed and also to change their way of worshipping God. (16-17)
trans-unit.note: !MAT!9~16#Answer:What do you think is the reason that Jesus spoke here about cloth, and about the wine and about hardened leather containers/bottles? What was he teaching the people?

group.id: Q:MAT 9.23+What do you think was the reason that they were there?

trans-unit.id: a:!MAT!9~23#Answer:What do you think was the reason that they were there?193412997
trans-unit.source: They were there because they had come to mourn the death of the little girl. (This is implied by the Jewish/Jews' cultural practice of having flute players come to play their flutes as a part of the/their mourning (ceremony) for a dead relative.) (23)
trans-unit.target: They were there because they had come to mourn the death of the little girl. (This is implied by the Jewish/Jews' cultural practise of having flute players come to play their flutes as a part of the/their mourning (ceremony) for a dead relative.) (23)
trans-unit.note: !MAT!9~23#Answer:What do you think was the reason that they were there?

group.id: Q:MAT 22.37-39+What answer did Jesus give to the Pharisee?

trans-unit.source: Jesus told the Pharisee that the greatest commandment is to love the Lord your God with all your being/heart and with all your soul and with all your mind. Jesus also told him that the second greatest commandment is to love your neighbor as you love yourself. (37-39)
trans-unit.target: Jesus told the Pharisee that the greatest commandment is to love the Lord your God with all your being/heart and with all your soul and with all your mind. Jesus also told him that the second greatest commandment is to love your neighbour as you love yourself. (37-39)
trans-unit.note: !MAT!22~37#Answer:What answer did Jesus give to the Pharisee?

group.id: Q:MAT 23.3+What did Jesus say to his disciples and the crowds about obeying the teachers of the law and the Pharisees?

trans-unit.source: Jesus told them that they must obey what the teachers of the law and the Pharisees taught/said. Jesus also told the people that they should not do what the teachers of the law and the Pharisees did because they did not do/practice what they taught. (3)
trans-unit.target: Jesus told them that they must obey what the teachers of the law and the Pharisees taught/said. Jesus also told the people that they should not do what the teachers of the law and the Pharisees did because they did not do/practise what they taught. (3)
trans-unit.note: !MAT!23~3#Answer:What did Jesus say to his disciples and the crowds about obeying the teachers of the law and the Pharisees?

group.id: Q:MAT 23.4-7+What did Jesus accuse the teachers of the law and the Pharisees of doing?

trans-unit.source: Jesus said that they loved the place of honor at banquets and the most important seats in the synagogues. (6)
trans-unit.target: Jesus said that they loved the place of honour at banquets and the most important seats in the synagogues. (6)
trans-unit.note: !MAT!23~4#Answer:What did Jesus accuse the teachers of the law and the Pharisees of doing?

group.id: Q:MAT 23.13-32+What were the seven warnings that Jesus gave to the teachers of the law and to the Pharisees?

trans-unit.source: 5. Jesus warned them that they did deeds to make others/people think that they were good/righteous, but inside their hearts/thoughts they were full of extortion/force/violence and self-indulgence/self-centeredness. (25-26)
trans-unit.target: 5. Jesus warned them that they did deeds to make others/people think that they were good/righteous, but inside their hearts/thoughts they were full of extortion/force/violence and self-indulgence/self-centreedness. (25-26)
trans-unit.note: !MAT!23~13#Answer:What were the seven warnings that Jesus gave to the teachers of the law and to the Pharisees?

trans-unit.source: 7. Jesus warned them that to cover up their evil and to make others/people think that they were good/righteous, they built monuments to mark the graves of/for the/God's prophets/spokesmen whom their ancestors killed long ago. They even decorated the graves/monuments of the righteous to honor them. They said that, if they had lived during the time of their ancestors, they would not have killed the prophets. But Jesus told them that, since they had tried so hard to cover up their evil intentions, they were just like their ancestors who had killed the prophets. He told them to go ahead and finish what their ancestors had started. (29-32)
trans-unit.target: 7. Jesus warned them that to cover up their evil and to make others/people think that they were good/righteous, they built monuments to mark the graves of/for the/God's prophets/spokesmen whom their ancestors killed long ago. They even decorated the graves/monuments of the righteous to honour them. They said that, if they had lived during the time of their ancestors, they would not have killed the prophets. But Jesus told them that, since they had tried so hard to cover up their evil intentions, they were just like their ancestors who had killed the prophets. He told them to go ahead and finish what their ancestors had started. (29-32)
trans-unit.note: !MAT!23~13#Answer:What were the seven warnings that Jesus gave to the teachers of the law and to the Pharisees?

group.id: Q:PHP 1.2+Who do you think God is?

trans-unit.id: a:!PHP!1~2#Answer:Who do you think God is?-2104096431
trans-unit.source: Key Term Check: In English, the term "God" with a capital "G" is used to refer to the one supreme Creator. The term "god" with a lower case "g", as in "a god" or "many gods", can refer to any spiritual being that people worship. The Greek word theos can be used in the same two ways. In many languages the term for God is a proper name and cannot be used to refer to anyone except the one supreme creator of the world. It cannot be pluralized.
trans-unit.target: Key Term Check: In English, the term "God" with a capital "G" is used to refer to the one supreme Creator. The term "god" with a lower case "g", as in "a god" or "many gods", can refer to any spiritual being that people worship. The Greek word theos can be used in the same two ways. In many languages the term for God is a proper name and cannot be used to refer to anyone except the one supreme creator of the world. It cannot be pluralised.
trans-unit.note: !PHP!1~2#Answer:Who do you think God is?

group.id: Q:REV 1.1+Who do you think God is?

trans-unit.id: n:!REV!1~1#Note:Who do you think God is?857612698
trans-unit.source: In many languages the term for God is a proper name and cannot be used to refer to anyone except the one supreme creator of the world. It cannot be pluralized. (Or, if it can be pluralized, the meaning may be something very different from the English "gods". In one language, the plural form of God, meant "God and those who follow him" and was an appropriate way to translate "saints".) (See "God" in KBT.)
trans-unit.target: In many languages the term for God is a proper name and cannot be used to refer to anyone except the one supreme creator of the world. It cannot be pluralised. (Or, if it can be pluralised, the meaning may be something very different from the English "gods". In one language, the plural form of God, meant "God and those who follow him" and was an appropriate way to translate "saints".) (See "God" in KBT.)
trans-unit.note: !REV!1~1#Note:Who do you think God is?

group.id: Q:REV 2.7+Where do you think paradise is?

trans-unit.id: a:!REV!2~7#Answer:Where do you think paradise is?-776499146
trans-unit.source: Key Term Check: It is heaven where God is. This word was used by the Jews as a name for the place where righteous people go, either when they die or when they rise from the dead and have been vindicated on the day of Judgment. It was located in the "third heaven" in Jewish thought of the time. (See "paradise" in KBT in the "heaven" entry.)
trans-unit.target: Key Term Check: It is heaven where God is. group.id: Q:REV 9.1+What do you think the abyss is?

trans-unit.id: a:!REV!9~1#Answer:What do you think the abyss is?379102885
trans-unit.source: Key Term Check: The word "abyss" (Greek abussos) literally means a place that is so deep that it has no bottom to it. In Jewish tradition it referred first to the water under the earth, "the deep". It also referred to the place where certain evil spirits were put in prison and tormented after being expelled from heaven. They will be kept there till the Judgment. The abyss (bottomless pit) has this meaning in Rev.9:1, 2, 11; 11:7; 17:8; 20:1, 3. (See "abyss" in KBT in the "Hell" entry.)
trans-unit.target: Key Term Check: The word "abyss" (Greek abussos) literally means a place that is so deep that it has no bottom to it. In Jewish tradition it referred first to the water under the earth, "the deep". It also referred to the place where certain evil spirits were put in prison and tormented after being expelled from heaven. They will be kept there till the Judgement. The abyss (bottomless pit) has this meaning in Rev.9:1, 2, 11; 11:7; 17:8; 20:1, 3. (See "abyss" in KBT in the "Hell" entry.)
trans-unit.note: !REV!9~1#Answer:What do you think the abyss is?

group.id: Q:REV 15.5+What do you think the tabernacle is?

trans-unit.id: a:!REV!15~5#Answer:What do you think the tabernacle is?654839150
trans-unit.source: Key Term Check: It is a place to worship God. The tabernacle was the portable sanctuary that the people of Israel built under God's direction in the early years of their history, while they were traveling in the wilderness. God was present in the tabernacle in a very special way. In some passages the reference is not to the man-made tabernacle which existed in this world, but to the corresponding tabernacle in heaven, the spiritual reality which the earthly tabernacle represents. (See "tabernacle" in KBT in the "tent" entry.)
trans-unit.target: Key Term Check: It is a place to worship God. The tabernacle was the portable sanctuary that the people of Israel built under God's direction in the early years of their history, while they were travelling in the wilderness. God was present in the tabernacle in a very special way. In some passages the reference is not to the man-made tabernacle which existed in this world, but to the corresponding tabernacle in heaven, the spiritual reality which the earthly tabernacle represents. (See "tabernacle" in KBT in the "tent" entry.)
trans-unit.note: !REV!15~5#Answer:What do you think the tabernacle is?

group.id: Q:1CO 8.8-11+Why then does Paul taboo the eating of food that has been offered to fetishes?

trans-unit.id: a:!1CO!8~8#Answer:Why then does Paul taboo the eating of food that has been offered to fetishes?132076489
trans-unit.source: Because if we eat it, and one who has a weak conscience [that is, one who believes that fetishes exist and have power] sees us, he will fall into sin. [He might also eat it and feel guilty. Or, he might become judgmental. Or, he might go back to worshiping fetishes and stop believing in Christ.]
trans-unit.target: Because if we eat it, and one who has a weak conscience [that is, one who believes that fetishes exist and have power] sees us, he will fall into sin. [He might also eat it and feel guilty. Or, he might become judgemental. Or, he might go back to worshipping fetishes and stop believing in Christ.]
trans-unit.note: !1CO!8~8#Answer:Why then does Paul taboo the eating of food that has been offered to fetishes?

group.id: Q:1JN 1.5-10+Who do you think God is?

trans-unit.id: n:!1JN!1~5#Note:Who do you think God is?857612698
trans-unit.source: In many languages the term for God is a proper name and cannot be used to refer to anyone except the one supreme creator of the world. It cannot be pluralized. (Or, if it can be pluralized, the meaning may be something very different from the English "gods". In one language, the plural form of God, meant "God and those who follow him" and was an appropriate way to translate "saints".) (See "God" in KBT.)
trans-unit.target: In many languages the term for God is a proper name and cannot be used to refer to anyone except the one supreme creator of the world. It cannot be pluralised. (Or, if it can be pluralised, the meaning may be something very different from the English "gods". In one language, the plural form of God, meant "God and those who follow him" and was an appropriate way to translate "saints".) (See "God" in KBT.)
trans-unit.note: !1JN!1~5#Note:Who do you think God is?

group.id: Q:1JN 1.6+If we say we have fellowship with God, but at the same time, we walk in the darkness/do evil deeds, what are we saying?

group.id: Q:1JN 1.9+What do you think happens when someone forgives someone else?

trans-unit.id: a:!1JN!1~9#Answer:What do you think happens when someone forgives someone else?-1290849087
trans-unit.source: Key Term Check: Forgiveness always involves two people, one of whom has done something wrong to the other and offended him. Forgiveness takes place when the one who was offended sets aside his right to justice and decides not to punish the offender as he deserved. If the one who offended repents and accepts this forgiveness, then the result is that the relationship between the two, which was broken by the offense, is restored, and the guilt of the offender is removed.
trans-unit.target: Key Term Check: Forgiveness always involves two people, one of whom has done something wrong to the other and offended him. Forgiveness takes place when the one who was offended sets aside his right to justice and decides not to punish the offender as he deserved. If the one who offended repents and accepts this forgiveness, then the result is that the relationship between the two, which was broken by the offence, is restored, and the guilt of the offender is removed.
trans-unit.note: !1JN!1~9#Answer:What do you think happens when someone forgives someone else?

group.id: Q:1PE 1.1+Who do you think God is?

trans-unit.id: a:!1PE!1~1#Answer:Who do you think God is?-1158108963
trans-unit.source: Key Term Check: He is the supreme being to be worshiped. In English, the term "God" with a capital "G" is used to refer to the one supreme Creator. The term "god" with a small "g", as in "a god" or "many gods", can refer to any spiritual being that people worship. The Greek word theos can be used in the same two ways.
trans-unit.target: Key Term Check: He is the supreme being to be worshipped. In English, the term "God" with a capital "G" is used to refer to the one supreme Creator. The term "god" with a small "g", as in "a god" or "many gods", can refer to any spiritual being that people worship. The Greek word theos can be used in the same two ways.
trans-unit.note: !1PE!1~1#Answer:Who do you think God is?

trans-unit.id: n:!1PE!1~1#Note:Who do you think God is?857612698
trans-unit.source: In many languages the term for God is a proper name and cannot be used to refer to anyone except the one supreme creator of the world. It cannot be pluralized. (Or, if it can be pluralized, the meaning may be something very different from the English "gods". In one language, the plural form of God, meant "God and those who follow him" and was an appropriate way to translate "saints".) (See "God" in KBT.)
trans-unit.target: In many languages the term for God is a proper name and cannot be used to refer to anyone except the one supreme creator of the world. It cannot be pluralised. (Or, if it can be pluralised, the meaning may be something very different from the English "gods". In one language, the plural form of God, meant "God and those who follow him" and was an appropriate way to translate "saints".) (See "God" in KBT.)
trans-unit.note: !1PE!1~1#Note:Who do you think God is?

group.id: Q:2PE 1.1+Who do you think God is?

trans-unit.id: n:!2PE!1~1#Note:Who do you think God is?857612698
trans-unit.source: In many languages the term for God is a proper name and cannot be used to refer to anyone except the one supreme creator of the world. It cannot be pluralized. (Or, if it can be pluralized, the meaning may be something very different from the English "gods". In one language, the plural form of God, meant "God and those who follow him" and was an appropriate way to translate "saints".) (See "God" in KBT.)
trans-unit.target: In many languages the term for God is a proper name and cannot be used to refer to anyone except the one supreme creator of the world. It cannot be pluralised. (Or, if it can be pluralised, the meaning may be something very different from the English "gods". In one language, the plural form of God, meant "God and those who follow him" and was an appropriate way to translate "saints".) (See "God" in KBT.)
trans-unit.note: !2PE!1~1#Note:Who do you think God is?

group.id: Q:2PE 1.17-18+What had Peter and [the other apostles] actually seen and heard?

trans-unit.source: They saw and heard that God really/truly honored Christ. (17-18)
trans-unit.target: They saw and heard that God really/truly honoured Christ. (17-18)
trans-unit.note: !2PE!1~17#Answer:What had Peter and [the other apostles] actually seen and heard?

trans-unit.source: What do you think it means when you honor someone?
trans-unit.target: What do you think it means when you honour someone?

trans-unit.target: Key Term Check: To honour someone is to show high regard or appreciation for them.
trans-unit.note: !2PE!1~12#Answer:What do you think it means when you honor someone?

group.id: Q:2PE 1.19+What does it mean to you to talk about the "heart"?

trans-unit.source: Key Term Check: The most common use of the word "heart" in the Bible is to refer to the spiritual center or innermost part of a human being. In Hebrew and Greek "heart" is most commonly associated with thoughts and ideas.
trans-unit.target: Key Term Check: The most common use of the word "heart" in the Bible is to refer to the spiritual centre or innermost part of a human being. In Hebrew and Greek "heart" is most commonly associated with thoughts and ideas.
trans-unit.note: !2PE!1~12#Answer:What does it mean to you to talk about the "heart"?

group.id: Q:2PE 2.1-10+What do you think it means if/that someone condemns someone else?

trans-unit.id: a:!2PE!2~1#Answer:What do you think it means if/that someone condemns someone else?1252591275
trans-unit.source: Key Term Check: It means that someone pronounces someone else guilty with the clear implication that the person will be punished for what he did. (See "condemn" in KBT in the "judge, judgment" entry.)
trans-unit.target: Key Term Check: It means that someone pronounces someone else guilty with the clear implication that the person will be punished for what he did. (See "condemn" in KBT in the "judge, judgement" entry.)
trans-unit.note: !2PE!2~1#Answer:What do you think it means if/that someone condemns someone else?

trans-unit.source: The land, which we passed through to search it, is an exceeding good land. If the LORD delight in us, then he will bring us into this land, and give it us; a land which flows with milk and honey. group.id: Q:EXO 20.2-17+List the Ten Commandments.

trans-unit.id: a:!EXO!20~2#Answer:List the Ten Commandments.-173025007
trans-unit.source: You shall have no other gods before me. You shall not make to you any graven image. You shall not take the name of the LORD your God in vain. Remember the Sabbath day, to keep it holy. Honor your father and your mother. You shall not kill. You shall not commit adultery. You shall not steal. You shall not bear false witness against your neighbor. You shall not covet. (2-17)
trans-unit.target: You shall have no other gods before me. You shall not make to you any graven image. You shall not take the name of the LORD your God in vain. group.id: Q:1SA 15.26-28+What did Samuel say regarding Saul as king?

trans-unit.source: The Lord had torn the kingdom of Israel from him and had given it to one of his neighbors who was better than he. (26-28)
trans-unit.target: The Lord had torn the kingdom of Israel from him and had given it to one of his neighbours who was better than he. (26-28)
trans-unit.note: !1SA!15~26#Answer:What did Samuel say regarding Saul as king?

group.id: Q:1SA 17.38-39+What did Saul provide David for the battle?

trans-unit.source: His armor, helmet of brass and a coat of mail. (38-39)
trans-unit.target: His armour, helmet of brass and a coat of mail. (38-39)
trans-unit.note: !1SA!17~38#Answer:What did Saul provide David for the battle?

group.id: Q:JDG 9.50-57+How did Abimelech die?

trans-unit.source: When Abimelech approached a tower in Thebez a woman of that city dropped a piece of a millstone on Abimelech's head, and broke his skull. As he was about to die he asked his armor bearer to kill him with a sword because he did not want it said that a women killed him. (50-57)
trans-unit.target: When Abimelech approached a tower in Thebez a woman of that city dropped a piece of a millstone on Abimelech's head, and broke his skull. As he was about to die he asked his armour bearer to kill him with a sword because he did not want it said that a women killed him. (50-57)
trans-unit.note: !JDG!9~50#Answer:How did Abimelech die?

group.id: Q:NEH 9.3+What did the Israelites do another onefourth of the day?

trans-unit.id: a:!NEH!9~3#Answer:What did the Israelites do another onefourth of the day?1539618426
trans-unit.source: They confessed, and worshiped the LORD (3)
trans-unit.target: They confessed, and worshipped the LORD (3)
trans-unit.note: !NEH!9~3#Answer:What did the Israelites do another onefourth of the day?

group.id: Q:RUT 4.1-8+What was the method of confirming a transfer of property?

trans-unit.source: A man plucked off his shoe, and gave it to his neighbor: (1-8)
trans-unit.target: A man plucked off his shoe, and gave it to his neighbour: (1-8)
trans-unit.note: !RUT!4~1#Answer:What was the method of confirming a transfer of property?

group.id: Q:LEV 18.6-20+With what persons of the opposite sex was an Israelite not to have sexual relations?

trans-unit.source: Those near of kin, including mother, step-mother, sister, step-sister, granddaughter, step-daughter, aunt, daughter-in-law, sister-in-law, woman put apart for her uncleanness, neighbor's wife (6-20)
trans-unit.target: Those near of kin, including mother, step-mother, sister, step-sister, granddaughter, step-daughter, aunt, daughter-in-law, sister-in-law, woman put apart for her uncleanness, neighbour's wife (6-20)
trans-unit.note: !LEV!18~6#Answer:With what persons of the opposite sex was an Israelite not to have sexual relations?

group.id: Q:LEV 19.16-18+How should we treat our neighbors?

trans-unit.source: How should we treat our neighbors?
trans-unit.target: How should we treat our neighbours?

trans-unit.id: a:!LEV!19~16#Answer:How should we treat our neighbors?-2135187120
